body:
Agreed, `GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE` is a much better default. That decision carried over from 2.x and I didn't reexamine it until 3.0 was already out.

Let's see what we can do about it in 3.x.

Since mixing any of these headers is a bad idea, we could perhaps add the falsely promised mechanism. Detect the canonical inclusion guards early on and ~define~ behave like `GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE` if any are present.

Switching the default would be the cleaner solution but it would also break the compilation of a lot of tutorial code, including our widely copied [minimal example](https://www.glfw.org/documentation.html).

Sorry, that was mostly just restating what you had already said.

Does this seem reasonable?
```diff

-#elif !defined(GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE)
+#elif !defined(GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE) && \
+      !defined(__gl_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gles1_gl_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gles2_gl2_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gles2_gl3_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gles2_gl31_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gles2_gl32_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gl_glcorearb_h_) && \
+      !defined(__gl2_h_) /*legacy*/ && \
+      !defined(__gl3_h_) /*legacy*/ && \
+      !defined(__gl31_h_) /*legacy*/ && \
+      !defined(__gl32_h_) /*legacy*/ && \
+      !defined(__glcorearb_h_) /*legacy*/ && \
+      !defined(__GL_H__) /*non-standard*/ && \
+      !defined(__gltypes_h_) /*non-standard*/ && \
+      !defined(__glee_h_) /*non-standard*/

```
__Edit:__ This diff has been updated with new variants after the comments below.

@elmindreda Glad you agree with me!

I'm reluctant to endorse that solution because there is such a long list of defines that appear in the wild, and it would need to be updated every time Khronos or a loader library adds or changes any of them.

Case in point, your proposed patch would not have avoided my issue as the header I get from glad guards with the following defines:

```
#ifndef __glad_h_
#define __glad_h_

#ifdef __gl2_h_
#error OpenGL ES 2 header already included, remove this include, glad already provides it
#endif
#define __gl2_h_

#ifdef __gl3_h_
#error OpenGL ES 3 header already included, remove this include, glad already provides it
#endif
#define __gl3_h_
```

not the `__gles`-prefixed ones. That's probably a bug in glad (I'll file an issue), but it proves how brittle this solution can be.

You could maybe add `__glad_h_` to the list (it's probably at least as stable as Khronos' identifiers), but there are a lot of other loader libraries out there...

IMHO the simplest fix right now would be to change the documentation to simply say that if using a loader library such as glad, the user *must* define `GLFW_INCLUDE_NONE` to guarantee no duplicate definitions.

You could do both, of course; I don't think there's any actual harm in guarding the most common identifiers.

issue.title: Inclusion guards for OpenGL ES headers

repository.name: glad
repository.description: Multi-Language Vulkan/GL/GLES/EGL/GLX/WGL Loader-Generator based on the official specs.

issue.body:
At the moment, GLAD guards against duplicate header inclusion using the following defines (in OpenGL ES mode; not sure if this is relevant to desktop contexts):
```
#ifdef __gl2_h_
#error OpenGL ES 2 header already included, remove this include, glad already provides it
#endif
#define __gl2_h_

#ifdef __gl3_h_
#error OpenGL ES 3 header already included, remove this include, glad already provides it
#endif
#define __gl3_h_
```

However, Khronos' headers use the following format:
```
#ifndef __gles2_gl3_h_
#define __gles2_gl3_h_ 1
```

Note the `gles2_` prefix. Should glad's defines not match the Khronos ones to function correctly?

I believe the library would also benefit from additional guards for the newer ES 3.1 and 3.2 headers.

Related to https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/1695

body: Both sounds like a good solution.

issue.body:
I found that the fix proposed in issue #1695 prevents `glu.h` from being included even when `GLFW_INCLUDE_GLU` is specified.

In this PR, I separated the section for `glu.h` from the section where the standard GL.h is included.
